columns.text:
While dividend growth is achievable at a greater dividend rate, the common stock would have a greater price.

Because of its preference above common stock in terms of payment of set dividends and debt repayment, if somehow the company becomes bankrupt, the preferred stock would have a greater price.
As a consequence, despite a similar dividend pay-out, most of these underlying features would influence the price of a company's common stock and preferred shares.
We need to determine if preferred or standard stock will have a higher price under the same dividend payment.

**Preferred stock** are stock with some unique properties but here are their main points:

1. They are ALWAYS paid out first and are always paid out to specific shareholders;
2. They always have the same dividend payment.

**Common** stock is standard marketable stock, with changing value and paid in appropriate time, there is no precedence for it.

Another property of the preferred stock is that **its dividends are usually at the higher value**. However, in this case, both a preferred stock and common stock have same dividend value.

Therefore, in this case, **common stock** will have a greater price than preferred, because common stock **is subjected to growth** and its price and its dividend can rise in value over time, while per definition **preferred stock is stuck with fixed amount**.
So, in this specific case, common stock wins due to non-fixed nature and can grow. However, in general, preferred stock will win due to inherently higher dividend value.

textbook.authors: Bradford D. Jordan, Randolph W. Westerfield, Stephen A. Ross
textbook.title: Fundamentals of Corporate Finance
